headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance: Top Stories for Aug. 31, 2010

headline: Putin on the Road
summary: During a four-day road trip across Siberia, a confident Vladimir Putin made clear he is still Russia's dominant politician. See a map with details on some of his stops.

headline: End of Combat Operations in Iraq
summary: President Barack Obama's Oval Office address and quick trip to the Army's Fort Bliss, outside El Paso, Texas, culminated a two-day commemoration of the end to combat operations in the seven-year-old Iraq War.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for Sept. 1

headline: Property Briefs
summary: A roundup of real-estate news

headline: Euro-Zone Unemployment Holds
summary: The euro-zone unemployment rate remained at 10% for a fifth straight month in July, indicating that despite strong growth in the second quarter, the recovery has yet to result in the creation of many new jobs.

headline: Inside Eataly
summary: Mario Batali and Joe Bastianich's Italian food and wine marketplace opens in the Flatiron district Tuesday. Here's a look inside.

headline: Rough August for Dow
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished the day up 4.99 points, or 0.05%, at 10014.72. Blue chips fell 4.3% in August, the measure's worst performance for the month since 2001.

headline: Digits | News and Insights from WSJ.com
summary: Digits | News and Insights from WSJ.com

headline: A Shooting in Israel
summary: Unidentified gunmen shot and killed four Israelis late Tuesday in what appeared to be a drive-by shooting outside a Jewish settlement near the West Bank town of Hebron, according to Israeli officials.

headline: H-P, Intel and Cisco Slide in August
summary: Stocks eked out a tiny advance on Tuesday, with AT&T, J.P. Morgan Chase and Merck among the gainers in the conclusion of a bruising month for the market.

headline: Alleged Bin Laden Aide Resentenced to Life
summary: An alleged aide to Osama Bin Laden was resentenced to life in prison for a brutal attack on a prison guard in New York in November 2000.

headline: Corporate Watch
summary: Corporate Watch

headline: In Sacramento, Debate and Theatrics but No Budget
summary: California's legislators aren't close to passing a budget to save the state from the imminent prospect of issuing IOUs. But they did put up a good show.

headline: European Shares Gain, but Fell 1.6% for August
summary: European stocks rose, as better-than-expected U.S. economic data warmed sentiment, but finished August with an overall 1.6% decline. Japan's stock market tumbled 3.6% Tuesday to a fresh 16-month low.

headline: Dennis Hopper, The Artist
summary: Though best known for his acting career, Dennis Hopper was also an accomplished artist and photographer. More than 250 paintings, sculptures and photographs are on view in "Dennis Hopper Double Standard," at the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art through Sept. 26.

headline: Preventative Surgery Cuts Breast-Cancer Risk
summary: Women who have mutated genes known to substantially increase the risk of developing breast and ovarian cancer were able to lower that risk if they underwent a mastectomy or had their ovaries and fallopian tubes removed, according to a new study.

headline: CFTC Unveils Retail Currency-Trading Rules
summary: The booming retail foreign-exchange industry won a partial victory after U.S. futures regulators backed off a plan that would have placed much stricter limits on borrowed funds used to trade currencies.

headline: Gates Speaks Cautiously on Iraq
summary: Defense Secretary Robert Gates, speaking somberly about the end of combat operations in Iraq, warned that now is not the time for "premature victory parades."

headline: Investors Superstitious About September Slump
summary: Investors left battered by the stock market's August tumult might want to prepare themselves for the September swoon.

headline: Photos of the Day: Aug. 31
summary: In Tuesday's pictures, an Indian farmer smiles for the camera, a couple represents Argentina in a tango competition, climbers straddle Hell's Gate in Kenya and more.

headline: Canada Still Holds 4th Terror Suspect
summary: An Ottawa man described by a Canadian federal prosecutor as a suspect in a year-long Canadian terrorism probe is being held until at least Friday by police on unrelated domestic-violence charges.

headline: International Business Machines, Berkshire Hathaway Cl B: Money Flow Leaders (IBM, BRKB)
summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

headline: Africa's Stolen-Drug Problem
summary: Roger Bate on how smugglers are diverting tens of thousands of donated pharmaceuticals into the black market.

headline: Australia PM Rejects Fresh Election Call
summary: Australian Prime Minister Julia Gillard rejected calls for an early return to the polls after the first inconclusive election result in 70 years.

headline: Oval Office Makeover
summary: The Oval Office will be sporting a new look for President Barack Obama's address to the nation on Iraq Tuesday night.

headline: Islamism Resonates In the Muslim World
summary: Responding to "Islamism Is Not Islam" (op-ed, Aug. 30)

headline: New Securities Issues
summary: The following were among recent offerings and pricings in U.S. and non-U.S. capital markets, with terms and syndicate manager, based on information provided by Dow Jones Newswires and Factiva.

headline: Moscow Detains Dissidents at Protest
summary: Police sealed off a central Moscow square and skirmished with anti-Kremlin activists, detaining at least three Russian opposition leaders and dozens of followers who were part of a defiant, surging crowd that included observers from the European Parliament.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Net Up 14%
summary: Bank of Nova Scotia's third-quarter earnings rose 14% from a year earlier on another record quarter from its Canadian banking operations, although results just missed analyst expectations.

headline: New Zealand's South Canterbury Collapses
summary: South Canterbury Finance collapsed owing about $1.4 billion, the latest in a string of financing companies that have cracked under the pressure of heavy debt burdens, liquidity issues and the bursting of the New Zealand property bubble.

headline: Earl Approaches
summary: Hurricane Earl lashed the northeastern Caribbean Monday and Tuesday, tearing roofs off buildings and cutting power to islanders, following a course that could bring it to the eastern U.S. later this week.

headline: Charge Unlikely Over 787 Delay
summary: Boeing's finance chief said the company should be able to absorb the financial impact of its latest 787 Dreamliner delay within the troubled project's existing budget.

headline: Rusal Swings to Profit
summary: Rusal said it swung to a first-half net profit amid higher aluminum prices and said it plans to launch depositary receipts in Russia this year.

headline: Queens Tudor With Global Flair
summary: After demolishing the existing home on a lot in Forrest Hills, Queens, the owners  spent $2.5 million to build a seven-bedroom Tudor with international influences.

headline: Crude Falls on Supply Concerns
summary: Crude futures tumbled, as investors turned their attention toward increasingly high U.S. oil supplies and the slowing economy.

headline: Fireside Cuisine
summary: Midtown's Fireside lures locals and out-of-towners alike with a menu that supplements comfort-food favorites with adventurous fare.

headline: European Markets Gain Ground
summary: European stocks finished up and well off their intraday lows, as better-than-expected U.S. economic data warmed sentiment in what had started out as a downbeat session for regional equity markets.

headline: KT Unveils New Tablet
summary: The price tag of KT's new seven-inch device will be about half that of its competitors, raising speculation that the device will try to compete with Samsung's  planned Galaxy Tab.

headline: Visteon Reorganization Plan Is Confirmed
summary: Visteon won confirmation of its Chapter 11 reorganization plan Tuesday after a bankruptcy turnaround that inspired bondholders to inject more than $1.25 billion into the auto-parts maker.

headline: Heinz Sees Higher Profit
summary: Heinz said preliminary earnings for its fiscal first quarter were 75 cents a share, an increase from a year earlier, as the company benefited from continued growth in emerging markets.

headline: Couche-Tard Extends Deadline for Casey's
summary: Couche-Tard extended its $1.9 billion hostile offer for Casey's General Stores again, even as essentially all stock previously tendered in favor of the deal has been withdrawn in the past month.

headline: Iraq's Failure to Form a Government Concerns U.S. Spy Officials
summary: U.S. intelligence officials see Iraq's inability to form a government as the greatest security threat to the country.

headline: Exelon to Acquire Deere Unit
summary: Exelon agreed to acquire Deere's renewable-energy unit for about $900 million as the electric-power company enters the wind-power segment and the equipment manufacturer focuses on its core business.

headline: Kerry Buys Luxury Hong Kong Site
summary: Kerry Properties bought a luxury residential site in Kowloon Tong for a higher-than-expected price at a government land auction.

headline: 3M to Buy Tracking Firm
summary: Conglomerate 3M plans to buy Attenti Holdings, an Israeli maker of remote monitoring technology used to track people.

headline: Ex-CEO Sues Abu Dhabi's Taqa
summary: Taqa faces a legal battle in the U.S. against its former CEO, who accuses the company, which has almost $25 billion in assets, of breach of contract among other allegations.

headline: Dollar General Boosts Full-Year View on Profit Rise
summary: Dollar General Corp.'s fiscal second-quarter earnings climbed 51%, topping analysts' forecasts, as the company saw its sales and margins rise.

headline: German Regulator Moves Against 10 Bank Board Members
summary: Germany's financial regulator has, in the first 12 months under new legislation, initiated removal procedures against 10 supervisory board members of banks because of a lack of qualifications, too many mandates or potential conflicts of interest.

headline: Bradley to Remain U.S. Soccer Coach
summary: Bob Bradley will remain coach of the U.S. national team through the 2014 World Cup.

headline: Advertising Rebound Boosts Havas
summary: French advertising group Havas reported higher first-half revenue and earnings as advertising markets recovered quicker than expected, but the company's organic revenue growth underperformed its major European rivals.

headline: USDA Sees Rise in Farm Exports
summary: The USDA, with a nod toward the drought that has knocked Russian wheat farmers from the export market, said it expects U.S. agricultural exports to increase 5.1% to $113 billion in the fiscal year ending in September 2011.

headline: Israel's Gas-Tax Review Draws Fire
summary: Energy companies have warned that any move by the Israeli government to increase its share of tax and royalties from natural resources may jeopardize investment in the country's nascent energy sector.

headline: Sun Pharmaceutical Unit Gets FDA Warning
summary: Indian drug maker Sun Pharmaceutical said its wholly owned U.S. unit received an FDA warning related to manufacturing practices.

headline: Gartner Cuts PC Sales Forecast
summary: Researcher Gartner cut its 2010 projection for world-wide PC shipments, saying sales will rise 19% but the second half won't be a strong as it previously expected.

headline: Bertelsmann Raises Forecast
summary: Media conglomerate Bertelsmann said it swung to a first-half net profit and lifted its outlook for 2010.

headline: BA Suspends More Staff
summary: Tensions between British Airways and cabin crew could escalate after trade union Unite on Tuesday disclosed that up to 80 staff have been suspended or sacked as a result of the dispute over working practices.

headline: Sadanand Dhume: Pakistan's Final Ignominy?
summary: A cricket match fixing scandal reflects a corrupt national culture.

headline: Japan 10-Year Yield Back Below 1%
summary: Japanese government bond yields tumbled as investors sold domestic stocks amid more worries over how the strong yen is affecting the economy.

headline: Carrefour's Makeover Is Unproven
summary: Carrefour's new hypermarkets are delighting customers. But they could take much longer to have the same effect on shareholders.

headline: Carrefour Eyes French Rebound
summary: Retail giant Carrefour swung to a first-half net profit and expressed confidence that it can turn around business in France.

headline: A Peaceful Home in Westchester County
summary: This five-bedroom home in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., has a loft-like layout, but potential buyers dubbed it "the peace sign house" because of a large symbol hanging outside.

headline: U.K. Consumer Lending Growth Slows
summary: U.K. consumer lending rose at a slower rate in July as mortgage lending remained lackluster, underscoring the view that the housing market will remain subdued for some time.

headline: Canvas Faces Mounting Opposition
summary: The launch of Project Canvas, a joint venture to bring Internet content and new video-on-demand services to U.K. television, in the first half of next year could be derailed after another company lodged its complaint about the service with communications regulator Ofcom.

headline: Japan's Tumble Leads Asia Stocks Lower
summary: Asian stock markets declined Tuesday, with Japanese shares dropping 3.6% to finish at a fresh 16-month low.

headline: Hontex to Compensate Investors
summary: Hontex International Holdings Co. said it plans to compensate investors after its audit committee found that statements in the company's IPO prospectus are unreliable.

headline: India in Pictures
summary: India at the field hockey Women's World Cup, Sania Mirza at the U.S. Open, rains in Mumbai and more.

headline: James Freeman: Glenn Beck's Happy Warriors
summary: You probably couldn't have found a more polite crowd at the opera.

headline: Taiwan PC Makers Post Profit Rises
summary: Taiwan's major personal-computer makers, Acer, Compal and Quanta, reported rises in second-quarter net profit, helped by a recovery in demand for electronic products.

headline: Japan Battles Soaring Yen
summary: Japan's central bank agreed at an emergency monetary-policy meeting to take new steps to rein in the soaring yen and pump up the slumping economy, in the latest sign of currency worries rippling around the world.

headline: Honda: No Plan to Sell Stake in Hero Honda
summary: Honda Motor and India's Hero Group both denied a media report that said the Japanese auto maker is considering selling its entire 26% stake in joint venture Hero Honda Motors.

headline: Centro Outlook Remains Dim
summary: Centro Properties signaled its recovery is far from complete, reporting a narrower annual loss but acknowledging that its debt load remains unsustainable.

headline: Lukoil's Net Slips on Higher Costs
summary: Lukoil said net profit for the second quarter fell 16% on higher taxes and export duties, a higher ruble and rising transportation costs.

headline: Ozawa to Challenge Prime Minister
summary: Japan's ruling party leadership vote in September will pit one of its most powerful memers, Ichiro Ozawa, against Prime Minister Naoto Kan

headline: Coal India Aims to Cut Stockpile
summary: Coal India is trying to arrange more rail wagons to transport coal and reduce the state-run company's stockpile by 24% before the end of March from the level at the beginning of the fiscal year in April.

headline: Taxing Times Could Help German Utilities
summary: Could a nuclear-industry tax be a blessing in disguise for German utilities?

headline: Japan Manufacturing Rises
summary: Japanese industrial output rose a seasonally adjusted 0.3% in July from the previous month thanks to growth in the general machinery and chemical sectors.

headline: Tiffany's Bags
summary: The famed jeweler is introducing a new leather collection, complete with handbags, wallets and gloves.

headline: Making Fools of Prudent Savers
summary: I am disturbed at the comment in your article "Fed Split on Move to Bolster Sluggish Economy" (page one, Aug. 24) that this country has "troublingly low inflation." One's viewpoint on inflation depends entirely on whose ox is being gored.

headline: IMF Expands Loan Options
summary: The International Monetary Fund said it would broaden the kinds of loans it offers to encourage a large swath of developing countries to get financial help before they are engulfed in crisis.

headline: Tire-d Old Trade Policies
summary: You can't boost exports by trashing imports.

headline: Merger-Arbitrage ETF Banks on Deal Pickup
summary: The IQ Merger Arbitrage ETF tracks an index designed to profit from the spread between an acquisition target's current stock value and the higher takeover price.

headline: Dark Clouds Boost Natural Gas
summary: Natural-gas futures jumped, ending an eight-day selloff as Fiona joined a parade of hurricanes making their way across the Atlantic Ocean and a government report showed U.S. production declining in June.

headline: Chrysler Sets Fiat Rollout
summary: About 400 Chrysler dealers gather in downtown Detroit to hear how they could help bring the Fiat brand back to the U.S. after a nearly 30-year absence.

headline: When Creator and Owner Clash
summary: What happens when an artist finds someone else has been "restoring" his work?

headline: Social Security Bait and Switch
summary: 'Harry, am I making this up?' Yes, Mr. President, you are.

headline: Chinese Stamp Record Set
summary: A set of "horse and dragons" stamps, originally commissioned by the Chinese Empress Dowager in 1886 for Taiwan, sold for about $1.3 million at a Hong Kong auction.

headline: Oudin Only Seems to Win in Queens
summary: It has been one long misadventure for Melanie Oudin since last year's U.S. Open, where she wowed American fans with fist pumps and daring winners during a run to the quarters.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: None

headline: Time to Talk at Genzyme
summary: Even tough opponents can be thwarted by a smoke screen. That appears to be Genzyme's hope.

headline: Back-to-School Shopping a Bust
summary: Shoppers spent slightly more last month than they had the year before, but sales were far short of 2008 levels, heralding what could be a disappointing holiday shopping season.

headline: U.S. House Travel  Stipends Are Probed
summary: Congressional investigators are questioning a half-dozen lawmakers for possibly misspending government funds meant to pay for overseas travel.

headline: Obama Builds a Big Tent . . . for Conservatives
summary: JOHN FUND ON THE TRAILThe rally demonstrated how the Obama administration's excesses have brought different strands of the conservative movement together.

headline: Los Angeles Uses Light to Fight Crime
summary: Los Angeles this year added eight parks to its Summer Night Lights program, which now keeps the lights on until midnight at 24 parks in neighborhoods with high levels of gang-related crime.

headline: McDonald's Growth Accelerates in India
summary: McDonald's plans to step up its rollout in India this year and next as it has discovered that the country's new middle class will line up for its fast food even in the smaller cities of the subcontinent.

headline: Theaters, Planes to Post Calories
summary: The federal government plans to expand posted calorie counts beyond restaurants to include thousands of other places that offer food, including airplanes, movie theaters and convenience stores.

headline: Master of Mustique Built Jet-Set Haven
summary: For much of the late '60s and early '70s, Colin Tennant— later Lord Glenconner— presided over a small island in the West Indies that epitomized what then passed for glamour. He died Friday at 83.

headline: Motorola Makes China Push
summary: Motorola unveiled a smartphone version of its handsets featuring a Chinese handwriting technology. Motorola is seeking to make a comeback in China.

headline: Genzyme Rejects Sanofi Offer
summary: Genzyme's board again rejected an $18.5 billion takeover proposal from Sanofi-Aventis, although Genzyme suggested it would be open to future talks if there were a higher starting price.

headline: Home Market: Lot of Looking
summary: The housing market in most of New York City is outperforming markets in the rest of the country this summer, with prices rising modestly as employment grows in the city.

headline: Intel, 3M and BofA Drop
summary: U.S. stocks fell in thin trading despite deal activity from Intel and 3M as investors continued to fret about the health of the economy.

headline: Bret Stephens: The Paula Abdul Theory of Foreign Policy
summary: Self-esteem does not make for good policy (or singers).

headline: Traders Warm to Campbell Soup
summary: Traders bet Campbell Soup's stock will hold steady or rise but took what looked like the opposite view on Limited Brands.

headline: Intel Looks Beyond PCs
summary: Intel's $1.4 billion deal to buy the wireless unit of Infineon demonstrates the chip giant's willingness to adjust its strategies to expand beyond the computer industry.

headline: Researchers Beaming at Light's Medical Uses
summary: Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology are studying how to replace diabetics' daily finger-prick blood tests with a beam of light.

headline: Stephen Hadley: Why We Fought and What We Achieved
summary: Saddam had launched multiple wars, used weapons of mass destruction and aided global terrorism. Now Iraq's government is an ally and represents all the Iraqi people.

headline: Jetliner Brake Systems Probed
summary: An American Airlines plane that careened off a Jamaican runway last year has prompted transportation-safety authorities to reassess how well some jetliner brakes perform in rainy conditions.

headline: Nation Should Mirror the Military
summary: Gary Schmitt and Cheryl Miller have it backwards when they say "The Military Should Mirror the Nation" (op-ed, Aug. 26). The nation should be like the military.

headline: A Clemens Trial Will Be Fun
summary: Roger Clemens, undaunted, pleaded not guilty Monday afternoon to federal charges of perjury. And he'll continue to fight—rolling over is not his style. Not when he feels he's been wronged.

headline: Japan's Move to Curb Yen Falls Short
summary: The Bank of Japan moved to tame the rallying yen, but the currency continued to rise.

headline: We Want to Be Optimistic, but That's Hard Just Now
summary: I have to admire Ross DeVol's attempts to put a positive outlook on our present business circumstances ("The Case for Economic Optimism," op-ed, Aug. 25). However, as a small-businessman, I would like to ask all politicians to shut up and go to a small business and see first-hand what the problems are.

headline: A New Kind of Baseball Math
summary: Pitches, not innings, may be best way for the Yankees to watch Phil Hughes's workload.

headline: Pachauri an Unlikely General in War on Global Warming
summary: When he first took the job, climate-panel chief Rajendra Pachauri was blasted by environmentalists as being a favorite of the fossil-fuel industry. Today he faces the opposite charge: being a green zealot.

headline: Medical Bracelets Go High-Tech
summary: New bracelets and other medical-identification systems can fill in first responders on practically a patient's complete health history. They're a far cry from the simple identification bracelets of the past.

headline: Samsung Seeks 'Apps' for TVs
summary: A push to control how Internet applications are created for TVs is kicking into high gear with Samsung planning to rally software makers around its own technology for making and distributing TV "apps."

headline: Disputes Precede Mideast Talks
summary: Palestinian and Israeli leaders, on the eve of peace talks, jockeyed for position with messages of peace, but held firm on disputed West Bank construction.

headline: Cab Attack Suspect Is Indicted
summary: Michael Enright, the 21-year-old film student accused of slashing taxi driver Ahmed Sharif last week after questioning whether he was a Muslim, was indicted on two hate crimes Monday.

headline: Japanese Men Vacation With Virtual Girls
summary: More than 1,500 male fans of the Japanese dating-simulation game LovePlus+ have flocked to resort town Atami for a date with their videogame character girlfriends.

headline: EFG Eurobank Net Slumps 61%
summary: EFG Eurobank Ergasias, Greece's second-largest lender by assets, said second-quarter net profit skidded 61%, weighed down by rising provisions on consumer loans and narrower margins.

headline: Jury Hears Bomb Plot Tapes
summary: The alleged ringleader in a plot to blow up a Bronx synagogue ranted about wanting to kill Jews in a videotape played for jurors.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Asia.

headline: H-P Settles Case for $55 Million
summary: Hewlett-Packard will pay $55 million to settle allegations that it paid kickbacks to win U.S. government business and other charges. The company also plans to add $10 billion to its share-buyback program.

headline: Andy Kessler: TARP and the Continuing Problem of Toxic Assets
summary: It was a bold bet that Treasury and the Fed could engineer an economic recovery without allowing the repricing of housing stock. A bad bet.

headline: Gunman Kills Eight in Slovak Capital
summary: A gunman killed seven people and wounded 14 in the Slovak capital before committing suicide, in the country's first-ever shooting rampage.

headline: Surfer Statue Stokes Controversy
summary: The botanical society in a California town thought it was honoring surfers when it erected a 16-foot tall statue of one riding a wave. Instead, it inspired a wave of humiliation for the hapless bronze dude.

headline: Uniting Against Cancer
summary: To date, Principal of Broad Street Development Ray Chalme and his family have donated $1.25 million to Uniting Against Lung Cancer.

headline: Alleged Drug Lord Arrested in Mexico
summary: Mexican police said they had captured Edgar Valdez Villareal, a U.S.-born alleged hit man and drug-cartel figure nicknamed "La Barbie."

headline: Viewership Remains Flat for Emmys
summary: About 13.5 million people watched the Emmy Awards, relatively flat from a year earlier, in a much-watched indicator for the event's organizers as they begin to negotiate a new contract with the networks that air the show.

headline: Short Sellers Take a Long Vacation
summary: Short sellers stayed on vacation this summer, even as the U.S. economic outlook darkened.

headline: New Twist on Classics
summary: BLT Restaurant Group's first  bar and grill turns classic American bar food into haute cuisine, without the hefty price or small portions.

headline: Tracking Planes on Ground
summary: New technology helps airports manage their ground traffic and enables airlines to beat hefty fines for long stays on the tarmac.

headline: German Bundesbank Faces Controversy
summary: Germany's central bank distanced itself from a board member accused of racism as it scrambled to contain the damage from a growing furor.

headline: Keeping Tabs on Kids
summary: Katherine Boehret reviews AOL SafeSocial, a tool for parents that scans sites where kids are social networking for inappropriate language or friendships.

headline: Where Can New Yorkers Play Tennis?
summary: Renovations across the city are improving the public tennis facilities, but work remains to be done.

headline: At Emmy Parties, Swag Sparkles
summary: Boiling it all down, the core root of the pre- and after-parties surrounding the Emmy Awards, it seems, are beauty products, writes Marshall Heyman.

headline: Biden Pays Visit to Iraq
summary: U.S. Vice President Joseph Biden landed in Baghdad, one day before Washington officially ends its combat mission here.

headline: Underlying Iraq Strategy, as So Many Others, Is Iran
summary: In Iraq, as in Afghanistan and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, one important goal is to clear the decks in order to concentrate more intensely on the paramount challenge posed by Iran and its Islamic extremist friends.

headline: Cricket Claims Deliver Blow to Pakistan
summary: The genteel world of cricket was engulfed in crisis as an alleged betting scandal prompted one of the biggest fraud inquiries in the game's history.

headline: Consumer Spending Grows Modestly
summary: U.S. consumer spending rose 0.4% last month but income growth remained sluggish, a sign the economic recovery remains fragile.

headline: MoMA Marches to the Beat of History
summary: The Museum of Modern Art is marking the 75th anniversary of the ground-breaking "March of Time" series, which brashly mingled news with Hollywood-style narrative techniques.

headline: I'll Put My Trust in The Open Internet
summary: Regarding Gordon Crovitz's "Is Technology Good or Bad? Yes" (Information Age, Aug. 23): According to Gallup, Americans are fed up with most professions. Just 9% of Americans place a high degree of trust in professional politicians.

headline: Salmonella Is No Danger to Vaccines
summary: This year's flu vaccine has some consumers worried. While it might protect them against a potentially deadly virus, could they end up infected with salmonella instead?
